paper_title.en: A Visual Stethoscope to Detect the Position of the Tracheal Tube

description.en:
BACKGROUND: Advancing a tracheal tube into the bronchus produces unilateral breath sounds. We created a Visual Stethoscope that allows real-time fast Fourier transformation of the sound signal and 3-dimensional (frequency-amplitude-time) color rendering of the results on a personal computer with simultaneous processing of 2 individual sound signals. The aim of this study was to evaluate whether the Visual Stethoscope can detect bronchial intubation in comparison with auscultation.
METHODS: After induction of general anesthesia, the trachea was intubated with a tracheal tube. The distance from the incisors to the carina was measured using a fiberoptic bronchoscope. While the anesthesiologist advanced the tracheal tube from the trachea to the bronchus, another anesthesiologist auscultated breath sounds to detect changes of the breath sounds and/or disappearance of bilateral breath sounds for every I cm that the tracheal tube was advanced. Two precordial stethoscopes placed at the left and right sides of the chest were used to record breath sounds simultaneously. Subsequently, at a later date, we randomly entered the recorded breath sounds into the Visual Stethoscope. The same anesthesiologist observed the visualized breath sounds on the personal computer screen processed by the Visual Stethoscope to examine changes of breath sounds and/or disappearance of bilateral breath sound. We compared the decision made based on auscultation with that made based on the results of the visualized breath sounds using the Visual Stethescope.
RESULTS: Thirty patients were enrolled in the study. When irregular breath sounds were auscultated, the tip of the tracheal tube was located at 0.6 +/- 1.2 cm on the bronchial side of the carina. Using the Visual Stethoscope, when there were any changes of the shape of the visualized breath sound, the tube was located at 0.4 +/- 0.8 cm on the tracheal side of the carina (P < 0.01). When unilateral breath sounds were auscultated, the tube was located at 2.6 +/- 1.2 cm on the bronchial side of the carina. The tube was also located at 2.3 +/- 1.0 cm on the bronchial side of the carina when a unilateral shape of visualized breath sounds was obtained using the Visual Stethoscope (not significant).
CONCLUSIONS: During advancement of the tracheal tube, alterations of the shape of the visualized breath sounds using the Visual Stethoscope appeared before the changes of the breath sounds were detected by auscultation. Bilateral breath sounds disappeared when the tip of the tracheal tube was advanced beyond the carina in both groups. (Anesth Anal 2009;109:1836-42)

description.en:
BACKGROUND: Advancing a tracheal tube into the bronchus produces unilateral breath sounds. While the anesthesiologist advanced the tracheal tube from the trachea to the bronchus, another anesthesiologist auscultated breath sounds to detect changes of the breath sounds and/or disappearance of bilateral breath sounds for every I cm that the tracheal tube was advanced. Two precordial stethoscopes placed at the left and right sides of the chest were used to record breath sounds simultaneously. When unilateral breath sounds were auscultated, the tube was located at 2.6 +/- 1.2 cm on the bronchial side of the carina. paper_title.ja: 等音圧面状に基づく声道面積関数の推定

paper_title.en: Estimation of area function from 3-D magnetic resonance images of vocal tract using finite element method

description.en: A study was conducted to develop a method for precisely estimating the area function from 3-D magnetic resonance (MR) images of the vocal tract. The vocal tract is usually divided by flat planes to acquire the area function from a 3-D vocal tract image, though this division is difficult as the shape of the vocal tract is curved. The calculation of the acoustic characteristics from the vocal tract image were obtained by the use of finite element method (FEM). The length of the vocal tract was determined as the sum of the subsection volume. The calculation of the area functions were carried by the use of section length and section volume. Construction of a loss-less acoustically equivalent circuit consisting of indicators and capacitors were used for calculating the area functions. The angle and the position of the planes were obtained with respect to the centerline.

paper_title.en: Estimation of area function from 3-D magnetic resonance images of vocal tract using finite element method

description.en: A study was conducted to develop a method for precisely estimating the area function from 3-D magnetic resonance (MR) images of the vocal tract. The vocal tract is usually divided by flat planes to acquire the area function from a 3-D vocal tract image, though this division is difficult as the shape of the vocal tract is curved. The calculation of the acoustic characteristics from the vocal tract image were obtained by the use of finite element method (FEM). The length of the vocal tract was determined as the sum of the subsection volume. The calculation of the area functions were carried by the use of section length and section volume. Construction of a loss-less acoustically equivalent circuit consisting of indicators and capacitors were used for calculating the area functions. The angle and the position of the planes were obtained with respect to the centerline.

paper_title.ja: 飽和潜水における高圧ヘリウム空気中でのダイバの聴力

paper_title.en: Hearing threshold of divers in hyperbaric helium-air gas mixture
Characteristics of headphones in hyperbaric helium-air gas mixture

description.en: The sensitivity of six kinds of dynamic headphones was measured using an artificial head with an artificial ear. The sinusoidal wave signal of 20 Hz-40kHz was amplified by an input amplifier and inputted to headphones set in the hyperbaric chamber. The pressure in the chamber was increased by adding hyperbaric helium gas to normal air in the chamber. Results reveal that when helium gas is added to normal air to heighten the pressure, the peaks and dips shift toward the higher frequencies.

publication_name.en: Journal of the Acoustical Society of Japan (E) (English translation of Nippon Onkyo Gakkaishi)
